尽管B-21的大部分开发都是“黑色的”，但出于可以理解的原因，罗珀的评论提供了一个有趣的窗口，让人们得以了解开发人员通常所说的由快速软件现代化带来的新一代传感、计算、定向和处理信息。他引用了一些术语，经过仔细检查，这些术语指出了一些能够大幅提高作战性能的技术现代化方法。
根据Kubernetes网站的说法，容器化软件是指能够对计算机操作系统进行编程，以同时简化和划分不同的功能，而不需要为每个应用程序启动整台机器。罗珀以Kubernetes为例，Kubernetes是一种用于“自动化应用程序部署、扩展和管理”的计算机系统。正如Roper所说，这其中很大一部分是通过所谓的应用程序容器来实现的；根据Techtarget.com的说法，它被定义为一种操作系统级别的“用于部署和运行分布式应用程序的虚拟化方法”。容器化支持多个“独立的应用程序或服务在单个主机上运行并访问相同的操作系统”。
通过利用支持软件的虚拟化，系统可以更快地升级，减少硬件占用空间，并更好地利用自动化、人工智能和机器学习应用程序。在全面战争术语中，这意味着B-21飞行员可以共享信息，发现并摧毁敌人防空系统…等目标。快多了。这可以加速精确武器攻击，识别迫近的空中和地面威胁，也许最重要的是，保持飞行员机组人员的生命。
经过新算法优化的人工智能应用程序可以吸收新的战争敏感信息，将其从看似无限的数据库中反弹，并快速执行比较分析，以做出决策，确定信息的优先顺序，并简化数据的组织和呈现，以供担任指挥和控制角色的人类操作。正如罗珀在他的帖子中所说，这个概念是为了更好地加快著名的OODA循环决策过程。OODA Loop，几年前由空军战斗机飞行员约翰·博伊德(John Boyd)出名，代表观察、定位、决定和行动。它指的是通过更快、更准确地完成OODA循环来进入敌人的决策过程，从而采取关键的生死行动来摧毁敌人…的重要性。再快点。
增加自动化背后的概念是通过自主地执行耗时耗能的程序功能(…)来减轻飞行员的“认知”负担。所有这些都让人类决策者在指挥和控制方面发挥着不可替代的作用。这样，动态的、有能力的人类问题解决能力可以在战斗中得到更充分和有效的利用。总而言之，飞行员将能够更快、更好地做出决定，因此正如罗珀在他发表的评论中所说的那样，“拥有OODA循环”。
集成的下一代软件不仅将成倍地加快对战争敏感的决策速度，而且还将提高武器系统的性能。比如武器制导系统、武器网络安全、处理速度和主要作战平台功能。飞机指挥和控制系统的远程传感器，当然还有聚集其他烟囱数据系统的程序，都可以通过软件升级进行优化。
所有这一切都与罗珀提到的“DevStar”有关，通过这一战略，空军一直在加快技术发展，以更快地将新一代武器和技术带入战争。根据Roper的战略愿景，这很大程度上依赖于软件集成和创新。空军DevStar的一篇论文将其描述为“速度、质量、专注和协作”。我们的想法是，至少在一定程度上，规避或简化冗长的、有时是官僚采购程序，以便在不影响质量的情况下，快速跟踪经过验证的系统投入战争。罗珀经常解释说，这其中很大一部分可以通过数字开发来加速，本质上是在“弯曲金属”之前对设计和技术系统进行建模。
Roper长期以来一直强调快速软件开发和集成的重要性，他曾一度告诉记者，软件现代化确实可能“决定谁赢得下一场战争”。
note_en:
The new stealth U.S. Air Force B-21 bomber has taken yet another key technological step toward being ready for war, through integrated computer automation designed to streamline information, improve targeting and offer pilots organized warzone information in real-time.
 Air Force and Northrop Grumman developers recently completed an essential software-empowered process intended to bring greater levels of information processing, data management and new measures of computerized autonomy, according to published statements from Air Force Acquisition Executive Dr. William Roper.
 Through virtualization and software-hardware synergy, B-21 sensors, computers and electronics can better scale, deploy and streamline procedural functions such as checking avionics specifics, measuring altitude and speed and integrating otherwise disparate pools sensor information. In effect, it means war-sensitive sensor, targeting and navigational data will be managed and organized through increased computer automation for pilots to make faster and more informed combat decisions.
 Roper’s post on LinkedIn explained it this way: The “USAF innovation hasn’t missed a beat during COVID-19. Our B-21 team just ran containerized software with Kubernetes on flight-ready hardware! Another step towards ‘DevStar’: our initiative to bring radical autonomy to software development, partnering with Northrop Grumman.”
 While most of the B-21 development is “black,” for understandable reasons, Roper’s comment offers an interesting window into some of what developers generally describe as a new generation of sensing, computing, targeting and processing information made possible by rapid software modernization. He referenced a number of terms which, upon closer examination, point to some technical modernization methods able to massively improve combat performance.
  Containerized software, among other things, refers to an ability to program computer operating systems to streamline and compartmentalize different functions simultaneously, yet without launching an entire machine for each app, according to “Kubernetes” website.  Roper cited Kubernetes, which is a computer system for “automating application deployment, scaling and management.” Much of this, as cited by Roper, is made possible through what’s called application containerization; it is defined as an operating system-level “virtualization method used to deploy and run distributed applications,” according to Techtarget.com. Containerization enables multiple “isolated applications or services run on a single host and access the same operating system.”
  By drawing upon software-enabled virtualization, systems can upgrade faster, reduce their hardware footprint and better employ automation, AI and machine-learning applications. In all-out warfare terms, this means B-21 pilots can share information and find and destroy targets such as enemy air defenses … much faster. This is something which can expedite precision weapons attack and identify approaching air and ground threats and, perhaps of greatest importance, keep pilot crews alive.
 AI-applications, optimized by new algorithms, can absorb new war-sensitive information, bounce it off a seemingly limitless database and quickly perform comparative analyses to make decisions, prioritize information and streamline the organization and presentation of data for humans operating in the role of command and control. The concept is to, as Roper put it in his post, better expedite the famous OODA-loop decision-making process. OODA Loop, made famous years ago by Air Force fighter pilot John Boyd, stands for Observation, Orientation, Decision, Action. It refers to the importance of getting inside an enemies’ decision-making process by completing the OODA loop faster and more accurately, therefore taking key life and death actions to destroy an enemy … faster.
 The concept behind increased automation is to ease the “cognitive” burden upon pilots by performing time and energy-consuming procedural functions autonomously … all while leaving human decision-makers in the irreplaceable role of command and control. This way, dynamic, capable human problem solving can be more fully and effectively leveraged in combat. In summary, pilots will be able to make faster and better decisions, therefore “owning the OODA Loop” as Roper put it in his published comment.
   Not only will integrated next-generation software exponentially speed-up war-sensitive decision making, but it will also increase performance for weapons systems. Things like weapons guidance systems, weapons network security, processing speeds and major war platform functionality. Long-range sensors for an airplane’s command and control systems and of course procedures to aggregate otherwise stovepiped data systems, can all be optimized through software upgrades.
 All of this pertains to Roper’s reference to “DevStar,” a strategy through which the Air Force has been expediting technical development to bring a new generation of weaponry and technology to war much more quickly. Much of this, according to Roper’s strategic vision, relies upon software integration and innovation. An Air Force DevStar paper describes it as “speed, quality, focus and collaboration.” The idea is to, at least in part, circumvent or streamline lengthy, at times, bureaucratic acquisition procedures to fast-track proven systems to war, all without compromising quality. Much of this, Roper has often explained, can be expedited through digital development, essentially modeling designs and technical systems prior to “bending metal.”
  Roper has long emphasized the importance of rapid software development and integration, having at one time told reporters that software modernization may indeed “decide who wins the next war.”

奇怪的是，黑氮不存在的想法长期以来一直被认为是一个谜。元素周期表按重复出现的“周期”排列，其中每一列都由具有相似属性的元素组成。那些在顶部的元素具有最少的质子和最低的重量，并且组中每一个连续的元素都增加了质子和重量。
在高压下，柱顶部的元素通常具有与组中更低的元素相似的结构。这些不同的形式被称为同素异形体。例如，臭氧是氧的同素异形体，而石墨和钻石都是碳的同素异形体。
但氮只有一种同素异形体-氮素-在其组中没有任何类似于较重元素的同素异形体。这一直被认为有点奇怪，但现在一项新的研究发现了一种以前不为人知的同素异形体，这表明氮并不像人们长期以来认为的那样是规则的例外。
为了创造新的形式，研究小组将氮气暴露在极端的高温和压力下。它在两颗钻石之间被压在一起，压力达到140万大气压，超过4000°C(7232°F)。在那些极端的条件下，氮呈现出一种以前从未见过的结构-但看起来仍然很熟悉。
当用X射线成像时，氮原子形成了晶状的二维层，呈之字形交联。它似乎具有良好的导电性，很像石墨烯，这可能使其在未来的电子设备中有用。
由于它与黑磷--相关元素磷的同素异形体--有相似之处，研究小组将这种新材料称为“黑氮”。
该研究的主要作者多米尼克·拉尼尔(Dominique Laniel)说：“测量数据突然为我们提供了黑磷的结构特征，这让我们既惊讶又好奇。“自那以后，进一步的实验和计算证实了这一发现。这意味着这一点毋庸置疑：事实上，氮并不是一种特殊的元素，而是像碳和氧一样遵循元素周期表的黄金法则。“
尽管黑氮在电子产品中可能有很大的潜力，但不要指望很快就能在你的智能手机中找到它。不仅由于上述极端条件很难生产，而且材料本身仍然不稳定，当热和压力放松时，它很快就会溶解。
拉尼尔说，由于这种不稳定性，工业应用目前是不可行的。“然而，氮在材料研究中仍然是一个非常有趣的元素。我们的研究举例表明，高压和高温可以产生研究人员以前不知道存在的材料结构和性能。“。

View gallery - 4 images   Researchers at the University of Bayreuth have created a form of nitrogen that’s never been seen before. Nicknamed “black nitrogen,” the new substance is crystalline, occurs in two-dimensional sheets, and could one day be useful in advanced electronics.
 Strangely enough, the idea that black nitrogen didn’t exist has long been considered a mystery. The periodic table is arranged in recurring “periods” where each column is made up of elements with similar properties. Those at the top have the fewest protons and the lowest weight, and each successive element in the group gains protons and weight.
 Under high pressure, elements on the top of a column usually take on structures similar to elements further down the group. These different forms are known as allotropes. Ozone is an allotrope of oxygen, for example, while graphite and diamond are both allotropes of carbon.
  But nitrogen only has one allotrope – dinitrogen – and doesn’t have any that resemble heavier elements in its group. This was always considered a bit weird, but now a new study has found a previously-unknown allotrope that shows that nitrogen isn’t an exception to the rule, as has long been believed.
 To create the new form, the team exposed nitrogen to extreme heat and pressure. It was pressed together between two diamonds to 1.4 million atmospheres of pressure, and over 4,000 °C (7,232 °F). Under those extreme conditions, the nitrogen took on a structure that had never been seen before – but which still looked familiar.
 When imaged using X-rays, the nitrogen atoms formed crystalline two-dimensional layers, cross-linked in a zigzag pattern. It appears to have good conductivity, much like that of  graphene, which could make it useful in future electronic devices.
 Because of its similarities to  black phosphorus – an allotrope of the related element phosphorus – the team has taken to calling the new material “black nitrogen.”
 "We were surprised and intrigued by the measurement data suddenly providing us with a structure characteristic of black phosphorus,” says Dominique Laniel, lead author of the study. “Further experiments and calculations have since confirmed this finding. This means there is no doubt about it: nitrogen is, in fact, not an exceptional element, but follows the same golden rule of the periodic table as carbon and oxygen do.”
 As much potential as black nitrogen might have for electronics, don’t expect to find it in your smartphone anytime soon. Not only is it difficult to produce due to those aforementioned extreme conditions, but the material itself remains unstable and it quickly dissolves when the heat and pressure are relaxed.
 "Because of this instability, industrial applications are currently not feasible," says Laniel. “Nevertheless, nitrogen remains a highly interesting element in materials research. Our study shows by way of example that high pressures and temperatures can produce material structures and properties that researchers previously did not know existed.”

在华盛顿特区、洛杉矶、旧金山、纽约和费城，苹果商店遭到袭击或损坏，抢劫者偷走了当时可以买到的任何产品。但这是苹果公司，任何人从那些零售店偷一部盒装iPhone都是令人头疼的。
人们早就知道，苹果公司运行着某种形式的接近软件，当设备被非法从商店拿走时，它就会禁用设备。然而，到目前为止，人们对这项技术的实际应用知之甚少。多亏了社交媒体，我们现在可以看到迎接抢劫者打开他们的新设备的消息：“这个设备已经被禁用，正在被跟踪，”它说。“将向地方当局发出警报。”
这些设备都不太可能按要求退回商店，但这不是重点。它们可能会被剥离成零件。更有可能的是，由于担心有某种形式的跟踪到位，他们会很快被抛弃。毕竟这是苹果。

对于那些确实丢失了iPhone的用户，苹果提供了一些有用的提示，告诉他们下一步该怎么做。但对于那些考虑从其商店偷一件的人来说，建议要简单得多--不要这样做。这不会奏效，而且可能会导致不受欢迎的敲门声。

As protests continue across the U.S., a week on from   the death of George Floyd  while under arrest in Minneapolis on May 25, those campaigning against “  police brutality ” have condemned as “  opportunistic ” the violence that has escalated across the country. Sunday saw “  a fifth straight of rioting and looting, resulting in another wave of arrests .” Apple, among other high-end retailers, has seen its fair share of attacks and has now taken action to protect staff and prevent further damage.
  Apple CEO Tim Cook   sent a message to his employees  as those protests escalated, saying that “there is a pain deeply etched in the soul of our nation and in the hearts of millions. To stand together, we must stand up for one another, and recognize the fear, hurt, and outrage rightly provoked by the senseless killing of George Floyd and a much longer history of racism.”
  Cook went on to say that “at Apple, our mission has and always will be to create technology that empowers people to change the world for the better. We’ve always drawn strength from our diversity, welcomed people from every walk of life to our stores around the world, and strived to build an Apple that is inclusive of everyone.”
     These words were being digested as the tech giant made the decision to close the majority of its U.S. stores for the safety of those staff and its customers, stores that had only just reopened after the COVID-19 shutdown. Apple has unsurprisingly become a favored target of looters, given the likely spoils on offer, and the decision was taken to remove stock from shop floors and shutter locations.
      Apple stores were attacked or damaged in Washington D.C., Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York and Philadelphia, with looters stealing whatever products were accessible at the time. But this being Apple, there is a sting in the tail for anyone stealing a boxed iPhone from one of those retail stores.
    It has long been known that Apple operates some form of proximity software that disables a device when it is taken illegally from a store. Until now, though, little had been seen of that technology in action. Well, thanks to social media, we can now see the message that greets a looter powering up their new device: “This device has been disabled and is being tracked,” it says. “Local authorities will be alerted.”
    It is unlikely any of those devices will be returned to stores as requested, but that’s not the point. They may be stripped for parts. More likely, they will be quickly dumped over fears there is some form of tracking in place. This is Apple after all.
  Looting apart, the theft of high-end phones—with iPhones top of the list—has been an issue in major cities for years. Apple has taken step after step to try to render its devices worthless once taken, including the sticky “Find My” functionality that enables users to track down an iPhone. “If your device goes missing,” Apple says “put it in Lost Mode to lock it immediately and start tracking its location.”
  For users that do lose their iPhones, Apple provides  useful tips as to what to do next. But for those considering stealing one from its stores, the advice is much more simple—don't. It will not work and may lead to an unwelcome knock on the door.

Pinebook Pro是一款14英寸、售价200美元的Linux笔记本电脑，采用ARM CPU，硬件通常是开源的，在社会上比较书呆子的群体中有很多令人兴奋的评论。有传言说，对于一块远远低于“便宜货”价格范围并进入“从卡车后面掉下来”的硬件来说，这是非常可靠的。然而，我最近看到有人抱怨说，有很多“新用户”的博客帖子，但没有“这是如何在六个月内真正起作用的”的文章。碰巧我把我的Pinebook Pro作为我的主要笔记本已经将近六个月了，所以我想我应该写下我到目前为止使用它的经历。
不同的人对笔记本电脑有不同的要求。我主要想要的是运行Linux的，足够轻，可以随身携带而不会大惊小怪的东西，而且我可以用来编程、游戏开发和游戏。也就是说，我通常和玩“末日永恒”或“XCOM 2”一样喜欢玩流氓游戏或旧的DOS游戏，所以我愿意在“游戏”方面相当灵活。
我在2019年12月买了Pinebook Pro作为玩具。我订购了它作为给自己的圣诞礼物，之后立即有了一些买主的悔恨。当时我有一台戴尔XPS 15，我非常喜欢。15英寸，坚硬的金属，足够轻，可以轻松携带，出色的CPU，相当好的电池管理，非常好(虽然不完美)的Linux支持。我为什么要把钱浪费在另一台笔记本电脑上呢？然后在一月初，我的XPS15在IHOP的停车场从我的车里被偷了，而Pinebook Pro是我唯一的笔记本电脑。(专业提示：当Lyft司机说社区不好时，即使看起来很好，也要相信他们的话。)。是时候快速适应了！它已经做了一些调整，也做了相当多的工作-它还不是即插即用的，硬件和驱动程序还相当年轻，所以这在很大程度上仍然是一台项目计算机。但它对我很有帮助，所以这里是我的经验。
还要注意的是，我在2019年底拿到了PBP，并不是每个PBP都是一样的；与大多数笔记本电脑制造商相比，它是非常新的硬件，而且是一家非常小的公司。他们似乎是分批生产，做一些次要的硬件，并在不同批次之间进行修改/修复。这些通常至少会在月度新闻博客上含糊其辞地公布。
外壳的顶部和底部都是金属的，键盘表面和屏幕边框是塑料的。整个东西重约1.3公斤，所以它非常轻，厚度不到一厘米。正如每个人都提到的，构建质量相当棒，总体感觉不错。我有一台800美元的笔记本电脑，感觉要便宜得多。你手腕的位置没有锋利的边缘(嗯哼，Dell XPS 15的设计师)，屏幕的铰链漂亮而僵硬，总体来说它是如此的轻便和僵硬，感觉就像是你可以把它扔进包或背包里，而不用担心它。这正是我想要做的。
你只需要一把十字螺丝刀就可以打开它，这很可爱，但是螺丝太小了，我担心会弄坏它们。(不过，如果我真的把它们弄坏了，嗯，我可以订购更换。)。不过，它的精致有点像是关于它内部结构的主题：盒子里有相当多的空白空间，但每件东西都很小、很薄、很精致，我不确定我会不会把它称为“可砍的”。主板大约有你的手掌大小，其余大部分空间都装满了电池。电线和连接器都是非常细的东西，可以塞进很小的槽里，很多东西都是用胶带压住的，或者塞进小小的凹槽里。你可以随意打开它，但要慢慢来，轻柔些。所有的设计和诸如此类的东西都是在线的-里面有一个可爱的贴纸，可以把你引导到他们的维基上查看硬件图表。但是，要真正做任何硬件修改，你可能需要一套很好的镊子，一只稳定的手，以及处理微小部件的神经。
这并不是说这一切本身就是坏事。它受到了充分的保护，我不指望它会破坏日常(Ab)使用，如果它确实破坏了一个新的主板，大约是100美元。嘿-它重1.3公斤。这就是你如何得到一台1.3公斤重的笔记本电脑的方法。我把它当作我的主要机器已经用了6个月了，还没有弄坏任何东西(更多，参见声音部分了解更多)，而且我对我的机器相当粗暴。我很容易就安装了M.2扩展板。所以，总的来说我是个粉丝。
说到这里，没有粉丝。除了扬声器格栅外，箱子上根本没有通风口或孔，所以现在我想起来，由于没有灰尘或其他粘性物质进入，这个东西实际上可能会持续相当长的时间。携带笔记本电脑去沙漠露营旅行或进入地下矿井是在市场上购买新笔记本电脑的一个很好的方式，但有了这个东西，我可能会在扬声器格栅上贴上一些管道胶带，保持键盘和屏幕的清洁，然后说它是好的。
不过，有一件很酷的事情是，我非常确定主板是99%未经修改的RockPRO 64单板。如果是这样的话，这是一个相当好的电路板，绝对值得考虑，而不是为你的下一个小单板计算机项目考虑一个Raspberry PI。唯一看起来不同的是连接器；所有大的笨重的连接器都被移除了，以便放入纤薄的外壳中，其中一些被移到了转接板上，以到达机器远端的端口。它使用与PBP相同的SoC，那么，为什么不使用整个电路板呢？
右侧：USB 2端口、耳机/麦克风组合3.5 mm音频插孔(也可通过适配器和硬件开关用作串行端口)、microSD卡。
左侧：电源连接器桶形插孔，USB 3端口，USB-C端口，也可以用来给东西充电，并作为DisplayPort视频输出。不过，我从未尝试过将其用于视频输出，所以我不知道它是否真的有效。
总而言之，这是基本的，但也是可行的。能再有一个USB2接口固然不错，但另一方面，它的USB接口已经比第四代同等大小的Macbook Pro还要多了。我更喜欢迷你HDMI或迷你DP输出，而不是试图通过USB-C将其分流，但那只是我是一个脾气暴躁的人。人们需要停止试图让USB-C无所不能。(如果你想拥有真正的狗屎时光，试着在灵敏的GPS接收器或远程WiFi旁边使用USB-C摄像机(例如，像Intel RealSense)。(不是与人民党，只是与任何事情。)。
仔细想一想，我认为它和你能找到的任何非机械式笔记本电脑键盘差不多。感觉不如老式的Thinkpad好，但可能至少和我用过的任何其他笔记本电脑一样好。它的布局和总体手感实际上和XPS 15几乎一样。空格键的两边都有整整一排的功能键、控制键和ALT键，所有这些都很好。没有什么比一个小小的退格键或者在某个奇怪的地方填鸭式的符号更奇怪的了。奇怪的是没有菜单键，但是，谁会用菜单键做任何事情呢？至少我不会。
布局有一个令人烦恼的地方：电源按钮是一个软按钮，映射到退格键正上方的一个键上，XPS 15将Delete放在那里。相反，Delete映射到fn-backspace。a)我不喜欢电源是键盘上的软键，我更喜欢离散的电源按钮，b)我希望有一个不需要按Fn和弦的Delete键，c)那个位置很容易被意外击中。事实上，我在写这篇文章时就是这样做的。这真是一件讨厌的事。
我也想要专用的向上翻页和向下翻页按钮，而不是FN向上箭头和FN向下箭头。但如果它需要一个不是同样制造的键盘，那就不是这样了。
不过，涉及到功能键(又名Windows键)和Fn键的某些键组合有一些奇怪之处。我过去常常映射功能-左和功能-右来左右交换桌面，我倾向于使用ctrl-pageup/pageddown键绑定来切换Firefox中的选项卡。不过，功能左键和功能右键不起作用，出于某种原因，ctrl-fn-down(又名ctrl-pageddown)起作用，但ctrl-fn-up不起作用。显然，键盘驱动程序是某种自定义固件，而不是简单地连接到内部USB端口，并且像所有其他固件一样，是开源的。我有点想深入研究代码，看看我是否可以修复它，或者至少看看它是怎么回事，就好像我需要另一个副项目一样。
我确实下载了一个较新的键盘固件，并在2月份左右刷新了一下，看看有没有什么不同，但当时没有。也许我应该看看有没有什么最新消息。而且，我一开始也没有意识到更新固件是一个中间重启的两步过程，所以它确实给我带来了重启笔记本电脑和让键盘只在控制台登录提示符中输出胡言乱语的令人心跳停止的体验。…。在我说“嘿，等一下，…”之前大约三分钟。至少还插上了USB键盘。
这是一个触摸板。它的表面下有两个按钮，因为这就是我们现在制作触摸板的方式，尽管它完全不如有单独的按钮。点击点击在默认情况下似乎不起作用，或者可能是我在某个时候关闭了它，然后忘记了。默认情况下，两个手指可以上下滚动。我读到过一些抱怨，说人们不喜欢这个触摸板，但虽然它可能有点粗糙，但对我来说，它似乎还不错。这不是我讨厌的苹果触摸板那种神奇的丝滑手感，但哑光处理感觉还可以，它在使用了几个月后，没有像我用过的一些廉价笔记本电脑，或者像我用过的几台相当昂贵的笔记本电脑(嗯，联想)那样，在表面上没有磨损一个洞。默认设置对我来说有点慢，所以您可能想在桌面环境设置中稍微调高指针灵敏度。
也就是说，我95%的时间都会使用外置鼠标，因为鼠标比触摸板要好。在任何Thinkpad爱好者对我胡说八道之前，鼠标也比小块头的东西更好。这两种都是暂时完全可以接受的，但长期使用是可以接受的吗？老鼠。
这是一台非常漂亮的1080p显示器。它是哑光的，而不是光泽的，客观上更好，我记得过去不得不多花一点钱从其他笔记本电脑制造商那里买到哑光显示屏。背光照明均匀，没有任何亮点或暗点，我真的能注意到。它在全阳光下太暗了，但在其他任何地方都很好，包括在阳光充足的阴凉处。与一些人不同的是，我对笔记本电脑上的1080p显示屏非常满意，特别是200美元的笔记本电脑。我的工作用笔记本电脑有4K显示屏，不错，但还不够好，我真的注意到了不同之处。我不能忍受的是720p的显示屏，这是一种需要在火灾中死去的分辨率，所以制造商在这里做了正确的事情，这对他们来说是件好事。
Pinebook Pro没有风扇；外壳的金属底部用作散热器。挺不错的。与大多数带风扇的笔记本电脑不同，你可以把它放在毯子上或腿上，没有任何间距，除非你一直在做一些让CPU保持最大运转的事情，否则它不会受到影响。
根据使用情况的不同，电池的续航时间从5-8小时不等。如果你真的在不停地敲打，可能需要3-4个小时。可能没有我们想要的那么长，但肯定足够长，可以经常使用一个下午，外加一些舒适的额外服务。屏幕上的背光大约占其平均用电量的一半，所以如果可能的话，降低屏幕亮度会有很大帮助。电源是15瓦，所以这真的是一个相当低功耗的设备。
Linux对CPU电源管理的支持完全可以接受。我强烈建议将Linux内核的默认电源模式设置为性能，而不是默认的平衡模式。cpufreq是您想要使用的工具，您可能需要编辑一个配置文件，使其在引导时应用您选择的设置。如果我没记错的话，在Debian上，它是/etc/init.d/cpurequtils中的一个变量。
默认电源附带一条1米长的电缆，该电缆太短。我应该抽出时间花15美元买一件更长的。在Mouser上找到了一个兼容的，但它似乎已经消失了…。哦，你可以从制造商那里得到一根更长的电缆，只需插入3A USB-A手机充电器即可。或者，您也可以使用3A USB-C充电器通过USB-C端口为其充电。其中之一可能是最容易的选择。
我唯一的抗议是它经常不能正确地挂起；如果你盖上盖子，它要么会挂起来，需要重新启动，要么永远坐在那里不动，吸电。我的XPS15过去经常做同样的事情，所以老实说，我不确定这是硬件/驱动程序的问题还是Linux的问题。
我买的这款机型有64 GB的eMMC闪存，它充当操作系统的主引导驱动器。我以为它是焊上去的，但他们卖的是替换的，所以也许它就是不知何故插进去的。以flash的标准来看，它的性能一般，这意味着它客观上相当优秀。比在SD卡或U盘上运行的Raspberry PI要好得多，所以那里没有难看的架构I/O瓶颈。我还花了整整7美元买了M.2适配器，还有一个512 GB的M.2固态硬盘可供/家使用。安装它很简单，虽然没有大箭头写着“M.2适配器在这里”，所以在打开笔记本电脑之前，你会想要查看一下图表，也许可以打印一份，或者把它准备好放在你的手机上。
Pinebook Pro不能(目前)从M.2驱动器引导，因为引导加载程序的配置有问题，也不能从USB引导。但将其设置为eMMC AS/和M.2 AS/HOME效果良好。它可以很好地从microSD卡引导；当我尝试不同的发行版时，让我尝试从microSD卡引导的发行版很方便，然后在我决定喜欢它时将其安装到eMMC上。安装到eMMC是很痛苦的，因为担心会把东西砌成砖头，但它运行得很好。目前，u-boot引导加载程序位于eMMC驱动器上的一组小分区上，因此如果您在安装过程中清除这些分区，您可能会对笔记本电脑进行砖块操作。我相当肯定，如果你这样做，就有可能拆开它，但这可能会涉及到拔出串行线和u-boot手册，我真的不想麻烦你。显然，在一个单独的芯片上有几兆字节的闪存供引导加载程序使用，但目前还没有人真正使用它来做任何事情。又一个有趣的副业，好像我需要另一个副业。
有几次我有神秘的硬锁，需要强制重启，这似乎与向M.2驱动器写入大量数据有关。不过，这种情况很少见。总有一天我会试着找到它。
它焊接了4 GB的RAM。如果你稍微谨慎一点，这就足够了，尽管Web浏览器会尽其所能让这一点变得困难。
老实说，这可能是最烦人的部分。由于某些原因，Linux上的声音总是一团乱麻，对我来说，Pinebook Pro也没什么不同。
首先，好消息是，所有的硬件似乎或多或少都在ALSA中注册了。或者至少，如果您在alsamixer中选择了RockChip-es8316-codec设备，您将获得比您想要的更多的设置和详细信息，充满了诸如“DAC攻击时间”和“ADC软斜坡”之类的低级胡言乱语。我从来没有尝试过任何东西，我只有通过PulseAudio才能真正工作。这样做基本上是即插即用的，尽管随之而来的是更多的问题，稍后将对其进行描述。
第二…。井。当我第一次买到Pinebook Pro时，我做的第一件事几乎就是打开它，安装M.2适配器和驱动器。在这个过程中，我不知何故给了其中一个扬声器一个很好的Yoink，它从外壳的狭缝中弹了出来，用它细长的电线摇晃着。它恢复得很好，但My Pinebook的外置扬声器已经属于“可以接受但很细小”的类别，总是发出可怕的、令人不安的嘶嘶声，让我感觉就像是在我的听觉之外发生了一声高亢的哀鸣。这就像我上的一堂音乐课，老师用合成器播放我听不到的声音，非常令人不快，同时除了微弱的白噪音之外，根本听不到任何声音。我经常怀疑它是否是我想象出来的-但如果我试图演奏一些东西，或者甚至坐在那里开着扬声器，但没有播放任何东西，我就能听出来，仅仅几分钟后它就像地狱一样不舒服。我胡乱摆弄了我能想到的一切，但没有效果：如果扬声器开着，它就在那里。我在网上找不到其他人提到这样的事情，所以我想知道我是不是把扬声器拿出来弄坏了什么东西。在我打开它之前，我从来没有试过播放声音，所以我没有比较的基础。
(哦，我记得我还在哪里经历过这样的事情：在直升机上戴着大功率降噪耳机。你的耳膜就像“我知道外面有很多噪音，但我感觉不到。”这绝对不等同于某些东西实际上是安静的！)。
不管怎么说。最后，我打开了Pinebook Pro Backup，完全断开了扬声器的连接。问题解决了；如果我想听什么，我会用耳机。它工作得很好。仍然有一点背景嘶嘶声，但这只是微不足道的白噪音，没有引起偏头痛的边缘。
此外，当扬声器出于某种原因连接时，即使我插上耳机，它似乎也只能检测到一个音频输出设备。任何声音都可以一直通过扬声器和耳机播放，而不是让我选择是输出到扬声器还是输出到耳机。完全违背了目的，不是吗？
此外，每当声音关闭时，它都会发出卡嗒声或爆裂声。其他人对此颇有微词，如果我试一试，也许我可以找到解决方案，但戴上耳机几乎听不到，所以我已经不再关心它了。
麦克风…。你知道吗，我想我从来没有试过用过内置麦克风？我刚刚试了试Pinebook Pro的外置麦克风，但根本不能正常工作。另一方面，我从来没有过不糟糕的内置笔记本电脑麦克风。我的工作机是一台价值2000美元的高端产品，装在一个精美的印刷盒里，用青春藤纸板之类的东西手工折叠，而内置麦克风仍然一文不值。将外置耳机插入Pinebook Pro的耳机插孔工作正常。
再次注意，这是在我对扬声器硬件进行了一次很好的测试之后，从2020年6月开始安装的Debian版本稍微有点问题。因此，根据硬件和软件的不同，您的里程数可能会有所不同。随着时间的推移，这些事情往往会变得更好。
无线网络正常工作。它有2.4 GHz和5 GHz两个频段，根据规范，理论上应该可以达到433 Mbps。在我的卧室里，现在，它轻松地超过了120 Mbps，所以它的官方速度已经足够快了。
蓝牙，我从来没有尝试过，因为我从来没有让蓝牙在任何计算机上，在任何操作系统上，在任何设备上可靠地工作过，从来没有。我只有一副非常漂亮的蓝牙耳机，和我的手机配对，只要我从来不碰它，这个设置就很好。其他的东西，都是铜的。
在软件方面，事情已经从“安装镜像最好是由社区成员随机组合的这个shell脚本来构建”变成了“几个大型Linux发行版的官方支持”。目前，我使用的是基本没有修改的Debian Bullseye安装，总而言之，它工作得很好。1月份的情况要艰难得多，但到目前为止，唯一真正的警告是，您需要安装至少具有内核5.4、IIRC的Linux，因为它包含了制造商贡献的大量RockChip特定的东西。早于该版本的内核版本。

note_en:
There’s been a lot of excited reviews among the more nerdly segments of society about the  Pinebook Pro, a 14-inch, $200 Linux laptop using an ARM CPU and generally open-source hardware. Rumors are it’s extremely solid for a piece of hardware that’s far below the “bargain” price range and into the “fell off the back of a truck” pile. However, I recently read someone complaining that there’s been lots of “fresh new user” blog posts and no “how does this actually work six months in” write-ups. It just so happens that I’ve had my Pinebook Pro as my main laptop for nearly six months now, so I thought I’d write up my experiences with it so far.
   Different people want different things from laptops. I  mainly want something that runs Linux, is light enough to carry around anywhere without a lot of fuss, and that I can use for programming, game development and gaming. That said, I’m usually about as happy playing roguelikes or old DOS games as Doom Eternal or XCom 2, so I’m willing to be pretty flexible on the “gaming” front.
 I bought the Pinebook Pro as a toy in December 2019. I ordered it as a Christmas present for myself and had some buyer’s remorse about it immediately after. At the time I had a Dell XPS 15, which I absolutely  loved. 15 inches, tough metal, light enough to haul around easily, great CPU, pretty good battery management, very good (though not perfect) Linux support. Why the heck did I waste money on another laptop? Then early in January my XPS 15 got stolen out of my car in an IHOP parking lot and the Pinebook Pro was my  only laptop. (Pro tip: When a Lyft driver says a neighborhood is bad, take their word for it even if it looks fine.) Time to adapt fast! It HAS taken some adaptation, and a fair amount of work – it is not plug-and-play yet, the hardware and drivers are fairly young, so this is still very much a project computer. But it’s served me well, so here’s my experiences.
 Also note that I got my PBP at the end of 2019, and not every PBP is the same; it is very new hardware and a very small company compared to most laptop manufacturers. They seem to manufacture them in batches do minor hardware and process revisions/fixes between batches. These are usually at least vaguely announced on the  monthly news blog.
   The top and bottom of the case are metal, the keyboard surface and screen bezel are plastic. The whole thing weighs about 1.3 kg, so it’s  light as heck, and less than a centimeter thick. As everyone’s mentioned, the build quality is pretty awesome, and it generally  feels good. I’ve had $800 laptops that felt far cheaper. There’s no sharp edge right where your wrist rests (ahem, Dell XPS 15 designers), the hinge for the screen is nice and stiff, and in all it’s so light and rigid it feels like you can just toss it into a bag or backpack and not worry about it. Which is exactly what I want to be able to do.
 You can open the thing up with just a Phillips screwdriver, which is lovely, but the screws are so tiny that I worry about damaging them. (Though if I do damage them, well, I can order replacements.) The delicacy is a bit of a theme on the internals of this thing though: there’s quite a lot of empty space inside the case, but everything is so small, filmy and delicate that I’m not sure I would quite call it “hackable”. The main board is about the size of your palm, and most of the rest of the space is filled with battery. Wires and connectors are all these fairy-thin things that fit in to tiny slots, lots of things are held down with kapton tape or tucked into itty bitty notches. Feel free to open it up, but be slow and gentle. All the designs and such are online – there’s a cute sticker on the inside that directs you to their wiki for hardware diagrams. But to actually do any real hardware mods you’re probably going to need a good assortment of tweezers, a steady hand, and the nerves to handle tiny parts.
 Which isn’t to say that any of this is  bad, per se. It’s protected thoroughly enough that I don’t expect anything to break from everyday (ab)use, and if it does break a new main board is about $100. And hey – it weighs 1.3 kg. This is how you get a laptop that weighs 1.3 kg. I’ve used this as my main machine for 6 months and haven’t broken anything yet (much; see the Sound section for more), and I’m pretty rough on my machines. I installed the M.2 expansion board pretty darn easily. So, on the whole I’m a fan.
 Speaking of which, there’s no fan. There’s no vents or holes in the case at all besides the speaker grilles, so now that I think of it this thing may actually last quite a long time due to lack of dust or other gunk getting into it. Taking a laptop on a desert camping trip or into an underground mine is a great way to be in the market for a new laptop, but with this thing I’d probably slap some duct tape over the speaker grilles, keep the keyboard and screen clean and call it good.
 One cool thing is though, I’m  pretty sure that the main board is a 99%-unmodified  RockPRO 64 SBC. It’s a pretty good board if so, definitely worth considering over a Raspberry Pi for your next small-single-board-computer project. The only thing that looks different is the connectors; all the big chonky ones have been removed to make it fit in the skinny case, and some of them moved to a breakout board to reach the ports on the far side of the machine. It uses the same SoC as the PBP, so, why not the whole board?
  Right side: USB 2 port, combined headphone/mic 3.5 mm audio jack (that also can be used as a serial port via an adapter and a hardware switch), microSD card.
 Left side: Power connector barrel jack, USB 3 port, USB-C port which can also be used to charge the thing and as a DisplayPort video output. Never tried to use it for video output though, so I don’t know if it actually works.
 All and all it’s basic but workable. It’d be nice to have another USB 2 port, but on the other hand, it already has more USB ports than a 4th gen Macbook Pro of similar size. I’d prefer a mini-HDMI or mini-DP output rather than trying to shunt it through USB-C, but that’s just me being a curmudgeon. People need to stop trying to make USB-C do everything. (If you want to have a real shit time, try to use a USB-C video camera (like an Intel Realsense, for example) next to a sensitive GPS receiver or long-range wifi. Not with the PBP, just with anything.)
  Upon contemplation, I think it’s about as good as any non-mechanical laptop keyboard you’ll find. Doesn’t feel as good as an oldschool Thinkpad but probably at least as good as any other laptop I’ve used. The layout and general feel is in fact almost identical to the XPS 15. There’s a full row of function keys, control and alt on either side of the spacebar, all that good stuff. Nothing weird like an itty-bitty backspace key or cramming tilde somewhere strange or such. One odd thing is there’s no Menu key, but, who uses the Menu key for anything anyway? Not me, at least.
 One annoyance with layout: The power button is a soft-button mapped to a key right above the backspace key, where the XPS 15 puts Delete. Instead Delete is mapped to  fn-backspace. a) I don’t care for power being a soft-button on the keyboard and would much prefer a discrete power button, b) I would like to have a delete key that doesn’t require pressing the  Fn chord, and c) that position is easy to hit by accident. In fact I did just that while writing this article. It’s a nuisance.
 I WOULD also like dedicated pageup and pagedown buttons instead of  fn-up arrow and  fn-down arrow. But not if it required having a keyboard that wasn’t built as well.
 There’s some weirdness with certain key combos involving the  feature-key (aka Windows key) and  fn-key though. I used to map  feature-left and  feature-right to swap desktops left and right, and I am partial to the  ctrl-pageup/pagedown key bindings for switching tabs in Firefox.  Feature-left and  feature-right didn’t work though, and for some reason  ctrl-fn-down (aka  ctrl-pagedown) works but  ctrl-fn-up doesn’t work. Apparently the keyboard driver is a custom firmware of some kind instead of just hooking into an internal USB port, and like all the rest of the firmware on the thing, is open-source. I kind of want to dig into the code and see if I can fix it, or at least see what’s going on with it, as if I needed another side-project.
 I did download a newer keyboard firmware and flash it in February or so, to see if it made any difference, but it didn’t at the time. Maybe I should see if there’ve been any updates. Also I didn’t quite realize at first that updating the firmware was a two-step process with a reboot in the middle, so it DID introduce me to the heart-stopping experience of rebooting my laptop and having the keyboard only output gibberish into the console login prompt. …For about three minutes before I said “hey wait a minute…” and plugged a USB keyboard in, at least.
  It’s a touchpad. It has two buttons beneath the surface because that’s how we make touchpads now, despite it being entirely inferior to having separate buttons. Tap-to-click doesn’t seem to work by default, or maybe I turned it off at some point and forgot. Two-finger scrolling up and down works by default. I’ve read some complaints that people don’t like this touchpad but while it’s maybe a little rough, to me it seems fine. It isn’t the magical silky Apple touchpad feel, which I hate, but it feels okay with a matte finish, it hasn’t gotten a hole worn into its finish after a few months of use like some cheap laptops I’ve used, or like a few rather expensive laptops I’ve used (ahem, Lenovo). The default settings feel a little slow to me so you might want to crank up the pointer sensitivity a little in your desktop environment settings.
 That said, I use an external mouse 95% of the time anyway, because mice are better than touchpads. And before any Thinkpad lovers give me guff, mice are better than the little nub things too. Either is perfectly acceptable for a while, but for long usage? Mouse.
  It’s a very nice 1080p display. It’s matte rather than glossy, which is objectively better, and I recall having to pay more than a little bit extra for a matte display from various other laptop manufacturers in the past. The backlight is evenly lit with no bright or dark spots I can really notice. It’s too dim in full sunlight but is perfectly fine anywhere else, including in the shade right next to full sunlight. Unlike some, I am perfectly happy with a 1080p display on a laptop, especially a $200 laptop. My work laptop has a 4K display and it’s nice but not nice enough I really notice the difference. What I can  not stand is a 720p display, which is a resolution that needs to just die in a fire, so good on the manufacturers for doing the right thing here.
   The Pinebook Pro has no fan; the metal bottom of the case is used as a heat spreader. It’s nice. Unlike most laptops with fans, you can leave it on a blanket or on your lap without any spacing and it won’t suffer unless you’re doing something that keeps the CPU cranked to max all the time.
 The battery lasts anywhere from 5-8 hours depending on usage. Maybe 3-4 hours if you’re really hammering it constantly. Probably not quite as long as we would want but certainly long enough to use it constantly for an afternoon plus some comfortable extra. The backlight on the screen accounts for like half its average power usage, so turning the screen brightness down when possible helps a lot. The power supply is 15 watts, so this is really quite a low-power device.
 Linux support for the CPU’s power management is firmly okayish. I strongly recommend setting the default power mode of the Linux kernel to  performance rather than the default  balanced.  cpufreq is the tool you want for playing with that, and you might have to edit a config file to get it to apply your chosen setting at boot. If I recall correctly, on Debian it’s a variable in  /etc/init.d/cpufrequtils.
 The default power supply comes with a 1 meter cable, which is too short. I should get around to shelling out the $15 for a longer one. Found a compatible one on Mouser at one point but it seems to have vanished… oh, you can get a  longer cable from the manufacturer that just plugs into a 3A USB-A phone charger. Or you can charge it via the USB-C port with a 3A USB-C charger. One of those is probably the easy choice.
 My only real protest is that it often doesn’t suspend correctly; if you close the lid on it it’ll either hang and require a reboot, or sit there forever still on and sucking power. My XPS 15 used to do the same quite routinely, so I’m honestly not sure whether this is a hardware/driver problem or a Linux problem.
  The model I got has 64 GB of eMMC flash memory on it, which acts as the main OS boot drive. I thought it was soldered on but they sell replacements so maybe it just slots in somehow. Performance of it is so-so-ish by flash standards, which means it’s objectively quite excellent. Far better than a Raspberry Pi running on an SD card or USB stick or any of that nonsense, so no ugly architectural I/O bottlenecks there. I also shelled out a whole $7 for the M.2 adapter, and got a 512 GB M.2 SSD to use for  /home. Installing it was trivial, though there’s no big arrows saying “M.2 ADAPTER HERE” so you’ll want to look up the diagram  before opening the laptop up, and maybe print out a copy or have it ready on your phone.
 The Pinebook Pro can’t (currently) boot from the M.2 drive due to something in how the bootloader is configured, and also can’t boot from USB. But setting it up to have the eMMC as  / and the M.2 as  /home works well. It does boot from microSD card just fine; when I was trying out different distro’s it was convenient to have the distro I was trying booting from a microSD card, then install it to the eMMC when I decided I liked it. Installing to eMMC is touch harrowing for fear of bricking the thing, but it worked out fine. Currently the u-boot bootloader is on a set of small partitions on the eMMC drive, so if you nuke those during the install process you might brick the laptop. I’m  fairly sure it’s possible to unbrick it if you do, but that will probably involve pulling out the serial cable and u-boot manual, and I don’t really want to bother with that. There’s apparently a few megs of flash storage on a separate chip that’s intended for a bootloader to live on, but nothing actually uses it for anything yet. Another fun side-project, as if I needed another side-project.
 A couple times I have had mysterious hard-locks that required a forced reboot, which appeared to be related to writing a lot of data to the M.2 drive. Very infrequent though. Someday I may try to track it down.
 It has 4 GB of RAM soldered in. It’s Enough, if you’re a little circumspect, though web browsers do their best to make that difficult.
  This is probably the most annoying part, honestly. Sound on Linux is always a giant clusterfuck for some reason, and for me the Pinebook Pro is no different.
 First off, good news, all the hardware seems to register more or less as it should in ALSA. Or at least, if you select the  rockchip-es8316-codec device in  alsamixer, you will get far more settings and details than you would ever want, full of low-level nonsense like “DAC Attack Time” and “ADC Soft Ramp” and other such things. I’ve never had any good ever come of trying to dick around with any of it, I’ve only had anything ever actually work by going through PulseAudio. Doing that is basically plug-and-play, though came with more issues that will be described in a moment.
 Second… well. When I first got the Pinebook Pro almost the first thing I did was open it up and install the M.2 adapter and drive. During this I somehow gave one of the speakers a good yoink and it popped out of its slot in the casing, dangling by its hair-thin wires. It slotted back just fine, but my Pinebook’s external speakers, already in the “acceptable but tinny” category, have alway produced a horrible, gut-disturbing hiss that made me feel like there was a high-pitched whine happening just  past my auditory perception. It was like a music class I had where the teacher used a synthesizer to play sound outside my range of hearing, and was  thoroughly unpleasant while at the same time not being audible at all as anything other than faint white noise. I often questioned whether I was imagining it – but if I tried to play something, or even had it sitting with the speakers on but not playing anything, I could  tell and it was uncomfortable as hell after only a few minutes. I screwed around with everything I could think of with no effect: if the speakers were on, it was there. I couldn’t find anyone else online mentioning something like this, so I wonder if I damaged something by pulling that speaker out. I never tried to play sound before I opened the thing up though, so I have zero basis for comparison.
 (Oh, I remember where else I’ve experienced that sort of thing: wearing high-powered noise-cancelling headphones in a helicopter. Your eardrum is like “I KNOW there’s lots of noise going on out there but I can’t feel any of it.” It’s definitely  not the same as something actually being quiet!)
 Anyway. In the end, I opened the Pinebook Pro back up and disconnected the speakers entirely. Problem solved; if I want to listen to something I use headphones. It works just fine. There’s still a little bit of background hiss, but it’s just barely-noticable white noise, with no migraine-inducing edge to it.
 Also, back when the speakers were connected for some reason it only seemed to detect one audio output device even when I have headphones plugged in. Instead of letting me choose whether to output to speakers or to headphones, any sound just played through both, all the time. Rather defeats the purpose, doesn’t it?
 Also, whenever the sound turns off it does so with an audible click or pop. This HAS had complaints from other people about it, and maybe if I tried I could find a solution, but with headphones it’s barely audible so I’ve stopped caring about it.
 Microphone… You know, I don’t think I’ve ever tried to use the built-in microphone? I just tried the Pinebook Pro’s external mic, and can’t get it to work at all. On the other hand, I’ve never had a built-in laptop microphone that wasn’t awful. My work machine is some $2000 high-end thing that came in a lovingly printed box hand-folded by artesinal cardboardéures or something, and the built-in microphone is still worthless. An external headset plugged into the Pinebook Pro’s headphone jack works just fine.
 Note again that this is with a slightly jank Debian install as of June 2020, after I gave the speaker hardware a good yank. So your milage may vary based on hardware and software. These things tend to get better over time.
  Wifi Just Works. It has both 2.4 and 5 GHz bands, and according to the spec should theoretically get up to 433 Mbps. From my bedroom, right now, it easily tops 120 Mbps, so it’s officially Fast Enough.
 Bluetooth, I’ve never tried, because I’ve never ever gotten Bluetooth to work reliably with any computer, on any OS, using any device, ever. I have a single set of very nice bluetooth headphones that are paired to my cell phone, and that setup works great as long as I never, ever touch anything about it. For everything else, there’s copper.
   Things on the software side have gone from “installer images are best built with this shell script a random community member put together” to “official support from several large Linux distro’s” extremely quickly. Currently I am using a mostly-unmodified Debian Bullseye install and all in all it works great. Things were a lot rougher in January, but by now the only real caveat is that you want at a Linux install with at least kernel 5.4, IIRC, since it includes a lot of Rockchip-specific stuff in it that the manufacturer contributed.
